titleStmt.title: SII 3.31: original edition by Eugen Julius Theodor Hultzsch
IV.—INSCRIPTIONS AT MANIMANGALAM. No. 31.—ON THE WEST WALL OF THE MANDAPA IN THE RAJAGOPALA-PERUMAL TEMPLE.

summary.p: This inscription belongs to the 48th year of the reign of Rājakēsarivarman, alias Kulōttuṅga-Chōḷadēva (I.), and opens with the same introduction as two inscriptions at Kāñchī, which I have published in Vol. II. (Nos. 77 and 78). It is dated on a week-day (l. 8) which, according to Professor Kielhorn's calculation,Ep. Ind. Vol. IV. p. 263. corresponds to Friday, the 25th January A.D. 1118. On this day a private person purchased from several other persons 1,050 kuḻi of land near the village and granted them to the temple, with the condition that the produce of the land might be used for defraying the cost of processions on new-moon days.

revisionDesc.change: Further conversion of digital encoding to DHARMA encoding scheme according to EGD (Encoding Guide for Diplomatic Editions)
Conversion of digital encoding to DHARMA encoding scheme according to EGD (Encoding Guide for Diplomatic Editions)

div.p:
svasti śrī . pukaḻmātu viḷaṅkaccayamātu virumpa nilamakaḷ nilava malarmakaḷ puṇara Urimaiyiṟciṟa[ n=ta maṇi] muṭi
cuṭi mīnavar nilai keṭa villavar kulai tara Eṉai maṉṉavariritariṟcuḻiTwo inscriptions at Kāñchī (Vol. II. Nos. 77 and 78) read maṉṉavaririyaluṟṟiḻi. tarattikkaṉaittuntaṉ cakkaranaṭātti vijayaābhi
ṣekam paṇṇi vīrasiṁhāsanattu Ulakuṭaiyāḷoṭu maṉṉi vīṟṟirun=ta- ruḷiya kovi(ra)rājakesaripanma
rāṉa tribhuvanacakravattikaḷ śrīkulottuṅkacoḻadevaṟku yāṇṭu 4 10 8 vatu kulottuṅka
coḻavaḷanāṭṭukkuṉṟattūrnāṭṭu maṇimaṅkalamāṉa pāṇṭiyaṉai Irumaṭiveṉkoṇṭacoḻa
caturppetimaṅkalattu m(ā)hāsabhaiyom Eḻuttu .The ta is entered below the line. nammūr vaṇṭuvarā- vatiThe e is entered above and the m below the line. Emperumāṉ koyilil śrīkā
riya(m)ñceykiṟaRead aḷḷūr. AḷḷurkkecuvapaṭṭaṉumThe first ṭ of paṭṭaṉ seems to be entered below the line. Araṇaipuṟattu tiruvāykkulapittaṉuṅkaṇṭu yāṇṭu 40 A tuThe figure a looks almost like va, and it is not impossible that the actual date is 4 10 vatu.
kumpanāyaṟṟuppūrvvapakṣattuRead dvitīyai. davititaiyum veḷḷikkiḻamaiyum peṟṟa cataiyattu nāḷ . Ivvāṇṭu mutal
Amāvāsi can=tirātittavarai EḻuntaruḷukaikkuRead rājendra. rājentricoḻavaḷanāṭṭu Ampattūrnāṭṭu nuḷappiyāṟṟu nuḷappiyāThe ppi of nuḷappi and the ppa of uṟappo in line 11 are expressed by a compound letter.
ṟukiḻāṉ veḷāṉThe word veḷ[ā]ṉ is entered above the line. perāyiramuṭaiyānāṉaThe syllable nā is entered above the line. taṇṭakanāṭuṭaiyānThe letter n is entered above the line. kuṇṭurRead ṭūr. toṇayakkiramavittaṉ pakkal Ālaimeṭṭil vilai koṇṭu
ṭaiya kuḻi nūṟṟirupattañcum . Iṅke madhyasta[nRead sthaṉ. U]ṟappon=tāṉum tampimārum pakkal vilai koṇṭuṭaiya kuḻi nūṟṟorupattañcumThe [pa] seems to be entered below the line. . Irāyūr tiru
pporikkiramavittan pakkal pātirikkaḻani melaikālukkukkiḻakku vilai koṇṭuṭaiya kuḻi nūṟṟirupattu mūṉṟum . Iṅkeyirāyūr viṣṇu tiruveṅkaṭakkira
mavittaṉ pakkal vilai koṇṭuṭaiya kuḻiThe ṟ of nūṟ is entered below the line. nūṟṟorupatteḻum . Iṅke Aiyakki vaṇṭuvarāpatipiccar pakkal vilai koṇṭuṭaiya kuḻi nū
ṟṟorupatum . Iṅke Irāyūr yajñanaārāyaṇakkiramavittaṉThe ra of kirama is entered below the line. pakkal vilai koṇṭuṭaiya kuḻi nūṟṟirupatteḻum .
Ālavatikku vaṭakkuThe ṭa of vaṭakku is entered below the line. Iraṇṭāṅkaṇṇāṟṟu vīravali tiruvaraṅkamuṭaiyāṉ sahaśraṉRead sahasraṉ. pakkal vilai koṇṭuṭaiya kuḻi nūṟṟirupa
tum . Iṅkey mūṉṟāṅkaṇṇāṟṟil IrāyūrāṉThe ṉ of rāṉ is entered above, and the n of ṉanti below the line. ṉantikkiramavi ttaṉ pakkal vaṭakkaṭaiyaThe two letters ṭaya are entered below the line. koṇṭuṭaiya kuḻi nūṟṟeṭṭum .
Arivāḷvatikkukkiḻakku mutaṟkaṇṇāṟṟu kkarāmpicceṭṭu nāṇamālaikkiramavit
taṉ pakkal vilai koṇṭuṭaiya kuḻi nūṟṟorupattañcum . Āka kuḻi Āyirattaimpatum Amāvāsi
ppuṟam cantirātittavaṟ celvatāka Iṟaiviḻuttukaikkukkirayamāka Ivar pakkal sabhaiyomāka veṇṭum
poṉ koṇṭu Iṉnilattukku vanta Iṟai sabhaiyome IṟukkakkaṭavomākaThe e [[kompu]] of vo is entered above the line. Icaintu Iṟai Iḻiccikkuṭuttom .
Ippaṭi kalliluñcempilum veṭṭiccantirātittavaṟ celvatāka Iṟai Iḻiccikkuṭuttomahāsabhaiyom .
sabhaiyuḷ niṉṟu Aiyyakki vaṇṭuvarāpatippiccar paṇikka paṇiyāl Eḻutineṉ Ivvūr madhyastan maṇimaṅkalamuṭai
yān veḷāṉ perāṉeṟṟiṉaRead perāṉ (ivai eṉ ?). Eḻuttu ..

(Line 1.) Hail ! Prosperity ! In the 48th year (of the reign) of king Rājakēsarivarman, alias the emperor of the three worlds, Śrī-Kulōttuṅga-Śōḻadēva, who,— while the goddess of fame became renowned (through him), while the goddess of victory was coveting (him), while the goddess of the earth became brilliant (with joy), (and) while the goddess with the (lotus) flower (i.e. Lakshmī) wedded (him),—had put on by right of inheritance the excellent crown of jewels; who had caused the wheel of his (authority) to roll over all regions, so that the Mīṉavar (Pāṇḍyas) lost (their) firmness, the Villavar (Chēras) trembled, (and) the other kings were defeated and suffered disgrace; and who, having anointed himself (in commemoration of his) victories, was graciously seated on the throne of heroes in union with (his queen) Ulaguḍaiyāḷ.I.e. ‘the mistress of the world;’ compare above, Vol. II. p. 391, note 8.
(L. 4.) The writing of us, the great assembly of Maṇimaṅgalam, alias Pāṇḍiyaṉaiirumaḍi-veṉ-koṇḍa-Śōḻa-chaturvēdimaṅgalam, in Kuṉṟattūr-nāḍu, (a subdivision) of Kulōttuṅga-Śōḻa-vaḷanāḍu.

(L. 6.) With the knowledge of Kēśuvapaṭṭaṉ (i.e. Kēśava-Bhaṭṭa) of Aḷḷūr and Tiruvāykkula-Pittaṉ of Araṇaipuṟam, the managers of the temple of Vaṇḍuvarāpati-Emberumāṉ in our village,—in the [48]th year (of the king's reign), on the day of Śatabhishaj, which corresponded to a Friday and to the second tithi of the first fortnight of the month of Kumbha.

(L. 8.) In order that (the god) might be carried in procession at new-moon from this year forward as long as the moon and the sun exist, Nuḷappiyāṟu-[Kiḻ]āṉ Vēḷāṉ [Pē]rāyiram-uḍaiyāṉ, alias Taṇḍaganāḍ-uḍaiyāṉ, of Nuḷappiyāṟu in Ambattūrnāḍu,This subdivision owes its name to Ambattūr, a village and Railway station west of Madras and 6 miles north of Saidāpēṭ. (a subdivision) of Rājēndra-Śōḻa-vaḷanāḍu,See below, p. 76 and note 15. purchased from Dōṇaya-Kramavittaṉ of Kuṇḍūr one hundred and twenty-five kuḻi at the Ālaimēḍu (hill).The same hill is referred to in No. 28, l. 9 f. In the same place (he) purchased from the arbitrator (madhyastha) Uṟappōndāṉ and (his) younger brothers one hundred and fifteen kuḻi. From Tiruppori-Kramavittaṉ of Irāyūr (he) purchased one hundred and twenty-three kuḻi to the east of the channel above the ‘Bignonia field.’The same field is mentioned in No. 28, l. 8 f. In the same place (he) purchased from Vishṇu Tiruvēṅgaḍa-Kramavittaṉ of Irāyūr one hundred and seventeen kuḻi. In the same place (he) purchased from Aiyakki Vaṇḍuvarāpati-Pichchar one hundred and ten kuḻi. In the same place (he) purchased from Ya[jña]nārāyaṇa-Kramavittaṉ of Irāyūr one hundred and twenty-seven kuḻi. In the second KaṇṇāṟuThe same term occurs repeatedly in an inscription at Tirumalai (Vol. I. No. 72). It seems to denote a group of fields. to the north of the Ālavadi (road) (he) purchased from Vīravali Tiruvaraṅgam-uḍaiyāṉ Sahasraṉ one hundred and twenty kuḻi. In the third Kaṇṇāṟu at the same place (he) purchased from Nandi-Kramavittaṉ of Irāyūr one hundred and eight kuḻi on the northern side. In the first Kaṇṇāṟu to the east of the Arivāḷvadi (road) (he) purchased from • • • KarāmbichcheṭṭuCompare above, No. 29, text line 22. Nāṇamālai-Kramavittaṉ one hundred and fifteen kuḻi.

(L. 18.) In order that these one thousand and fifty kuḻiBy adding up the preceding amounts we arrive at 1,060 kuḻi, i.e. 10 more than stated in the text. might continue as long as the moon and the sun, for providingOn puṟam see above, p. 6, note 9. (the processions) at new-moon,—having received from him as purchaser the gold necessary for making (the land) tax-free, we, the assembly, gave (it) free of taxes, agreeing that we, the assembly, shall have to pay the taxes due on this land.
(L. 21.) Having engraved this on stone and copper, we, the great assembly, gave (it) free of taxes, to continue as long as the moon and the sun.

(L. 22.) Having been present in the assembly, I, the arbitrator of this village, Maṇimaṅgalam-uḍaiyāṉ Vēḷāṉ Pērāṉ, wrote (the above) at the order of Aiyyakki Vaṇḍuvarāpati-Pichchar. This (is) my writing.
Digital edition of SII 3.31 by converted to DHARMA conventions by Emmanuel Francis.
